fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.env

Class SimpleConverterBuilder<P>

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.fluent.AbstractParent<P>
      • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.env.SimpleConverterBuilder<P>
  • Type Parameters:
    P - the type of the parent builder (when calling AbstractParent.and() method)
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<Converter>, ConverterBuilder<P>, Parent<P>

    public class SimpleConverterBuilder<P>
extends AbstractParent<P>
implements ConverterBuilder<P>
    A ConverterBuilder that builds the converter:
    • If a custom converter is defined, use it
    • If no custom converter, use DefaultConverter
    • If DefaultConverter or custom converter that also implements ConverterRegistry, register all previously registered SupportingConverters
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • override

        public SimpleConverterBuilder<P> override(Converter converter)
        Description copied from interface: ConverterBuilder
        Provide your own converter implementation.

        If your custom implementation also implements ConverterRegistry interface, you can still use ConverterBuilder.register(SupportingConverter) to register specific converters. If it doesn't implement ConverterRegistry, calling ConverterBuilder.register(SupportingConverter) has no effect.

        If null value is set, it disables custom converter and default converter is used.

        Specified by:
        override in interface ConverterBuilder<P>
        Parameters:
        converter - the custom converter to use
        Returns:
        this instance of fluent use

      • register

        public SimpleConverterBuilder<P> register(SupportingConverter converter)
        Description copied from interface: ConverterBuilder
        Register a custom converter. By default, DefaultConverter implementation is used. This implementation also implements ConverterRegistry. So any registered converter is registered in the ConverterRegistry.

        The DefaultConverter implementation delegates all conversions to registered SupportingConverters.

        If you don't want to use DefaultConverter but use your own implementation, use ConverterBuilder.override(Converter) method.

        Specified by:
        register in interface ConverterBuilder<P>
        Parameters:
        converter - the converter to register into the ConverterRegistry
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • defaultConverter

        public ConverterBuilder<P> defaultConverter(MayOverride<Converter> converter)
        Description copied from interface: ConverterBuilder
        Provide the default converter implementation.

        The default converter is used if ConverterBuilder.override(Converter) is never used or has been set to null.

        If converter implementation also implements ConverterRegistry interface, you can still use ConverterBuilder.register(SupportingConverter) to register specific converters. If it doesn't implement ConverterRegistry, calling ConverterBuilder.register(SupportingConverter) has no effect.

        Automatic configuration is based on priority order. Higher priority is applied first. It means that the lowest priority is applied last and overrides any default value set by a Configurer with higher priority using ConverterBuilder.override(Converter).

        This method gives more control on how Configurers should provide a default converter. Each Configurer can decide if its default converter should override or not a previously default converter set by a Configurer with higher priority. It can also be used to control default converter override or not with null value.

        If every Configurer uses MayOverride.overrideIfNotSet(Object): 

         .defaultConverter(MayOverride.overrideIfNotSet(new DefaultConverter()))
        Then the default converter comes from the first applied Configurer (the one with highest priority) that sets a non-null default converter.
        Specified by:
        defaultConverter in interface ConverterBuilder<P>
        Parameters:
        converter - the custom converter to use
        Returns:
        this instance of fluent use

      • build

        public Converter build()
        Build the converter:
        • If a custom converter is defined, use it
        • If no custom converter, use DefaultConverter
        • If DefaultConverter or custom converter that also implements ConverterRegistry, register all previously registered SupportingConverters
        Specified by:
        build in interface Builder<Converter>
        Returns:
        The built instance
